title_sort: susan stafford to walt whitman, 31 january 1877
title: Susan Stafford to Walt Whitman, 31 January 1877
text: HomeWednsday[Wednesday] EveningJan 31/77Dear friendwe recieved[received] your wellcome[welcome] Letter last evenigng[evening] & was glad to hear from you & to know that you are well & happy with your friends in the City. we are all well as usual I have just returned home from Red Bank where I willed to se[see] of my Dear Mother who is at this time to all appearences[appearances] near Death to day[today] when I left her I felt that it would be the last time that I should se[see] her alive. Dear frend[friend] you can judge of my feelings better than I cncan discribe[describe] them. we shall look fore[for] you down with us Teusday[Tuesday] but please do not think of going back in one day I shoul[should] not get go to se[see] you at allsurely you can give us more Than one day from your friends I know they can make you more comefortable[comfortable] than we can but they do not care fore[for] you more than we tionsever your friendS M. Stafford Susan Stafford to Walt Whitman, 31 January 1877
